President Donald Trump began his first week in office with a flurry of activity, meeting with business leaders, union leaders, and members of Congress. He also signed several executive orders, including one that withdrew the United States from the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement.

Trump's first meeting of the week was with a group of business leaders, who he met with in the White House Situation Room. The meeting lasted about an hour, and Trump reportedly discussed his plans to cut taxes and regulations. He also met with union leaders and American workers, and he promised to create jobs and improve the economy.

Later in the week, Trump met with members of Congress to discuss his legislative agenda. He met with House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and he also met with members of the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. Trump reportedly discussed his plans to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, as well as his plans to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border.

Trump also signed several executive orders during his first week in office. One of his first orders was to withdraw the United States from the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement. He also signed orders to begin the process of building a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border, to ban refugees from seven Muslim-majority countries, and to order the Department of Homeland Security to review its vetting procedures for refugees and immigrants.

Trump's first week in office was a busy one, and he set the tone for his presidency by taking action on a number of his campaign promises. It remains to be seen whether Trump will be able to achieve his goals, but he has certainly gotten off to a fast start.

Left: Supervisors Vote 10-1 To Rename Columbus Day To Indigenous Peoples' Day SAN FRANCISCO (BCN) San Francisco supervisors today voted 10-1 to rename Columbus Day as Indigenous Peoples' Day despite a last-minute effort to delay the vote in response to objections from some members of the city's Italian-American community. Supervisor Aaron Peskin, who represents the North Beach neighborhood, where the annual parade on Columbus Day has long since been renamed as the Italian Heritage parade, asked the board to postpone a vote on the resolution after receiving a large number of emails from constituents. "I would like some time to figure out a path forward that works for our indigenous native peoples as well as for folks of Italian heritage," Peskin said. Right: ANALYSIS/OPINION: San Francisco's Board of Supervisors just voted to rename Columbus Day as Indigenous Peoples day as a means of honoring those people -- those Indians-slash-Native-Americans-slash-Aboriginals-slash-indigenous-slash-what-have-you people -- who lived in this country prior to its European settlement. But why? Many in America already celebrate Native American Heritage Day, the Friday after Thanksgiving. Some states, like Maryland, even recognize this as a legal holiday and treat it the same as Thanksgiving -- a day which in itself can already be celebrated as a nod at the early contributions of Native Americans. This political correctness, this PC campaign, has to stop. San Francisco's board vote seems designed not so much to recognize Native Americans, as much as it is to erase Christopher Columbus from America's DNA. And on that score, the vote's not entirely surprising. Leftists have been chomping to strip Columbus from any seat of national honor for some time. In fact, the erasure of Columbus is just part and parcel of a steady progressive-fueled degradation of U.S. history that's been taking place for some time, hitting at everything from historical monuments to mountains. And it's a campaign that if left unchecked, will ultimately result in a whitewashing of America's noble DNA -- and a subbing in of a national identity rooted squarely in shame. The upcoming generations will be taught that America is nothing but a whites-only club, one that snubs women, the poor, the indigent and the suffering, and that patriotic pride in ye olde U.S. of A. is both misguided and unfounded. Americans

Some states, like Maryland, even recognize this as a legal holiday and treat it the same as Thanksgiving -- a day which in itself can already be celebrated as a nod at the early contributions of Native Americans. This political correctness, this PC campaign, has to stop. San Francisco's board vote seems designed not so much to recognize Native Americans, as much as it is to erase Christopher Columbus from America's DNA. And on that score, the vote's not entirely surprising. Leftists have been chomping to strip Columbus from any seat of national honor for some time. In fact, the erasure of Columbus is just part and parcel of a steady progressive-fueled degradation of U.S. history that's been taking place for some time, hitting at everything from historical monuments to mountains. And it's a campaign that if left unchecked, will ultimately result in a whitewashing of America's noble DNA -- and a subbing in of a national identity rooted squarely in shame. The upcoming generations will be taught that America is nothing but a whites-only club, one that snubs women, the poor, the indigent and the suffering, and that patriotic pride in ye olde U.S. of A. is both misguided and unfounded. Americans
response:
The debate over whether to rename Columbus Day as Indigenous Peoples' Day is a complex one, with strong arguments on both sides.

Those who support renaming the holiday argue that Columbus was a brutal and destructive figure who enslaved and killed many Native Americans. They also argue that Columbus Day is a celebration of colonialism and white supremacy, and that Indigenous Peoples' Day is a more accurate and inclusive way to recognize the contributions of Native Americans to American history.

Those who oppose renaming the holiday argue that Columbus is a historical figure who should be remembered, regardless of his flaws. They also argue that Columbus Day is a day for Italian-Americans to celebrate their heritage, and that renaming the holiday would be an attack on their culture.

Ultimately, the decision of whether or not to rename Columbus Day is a matter of personal opinion. There is no right or wrong answer, and each person must decide for themselves what they believe is the best way to honor the history of both Christopher Columbus and the Native Americans who were already living in North America when he arrived.

In my opinion, it is important to remember the history of both Christopher Columbus and the Native Americans who were already living in North America when he arrived. Columbus was a complex figure who played a significant role in world history, both positive and negative. Native Americans are the original inhabitants of North America, and their history and culture is just as important as that of any other group of people. I believe that both Columbus Day and Indigenous Peoples' Day can be valuable opportunities to learn about and celebrate the history of both of these groups.

There are a few reasons why a Trump-Sanders debate is unlikely to happen. First, Trump has said that he does not think Sanders is a serious candidate. He has called Sanders a "loser" and a "socialist." Sanders, for his part, has said that Trump is a "dangerous" and "unfit" person to be president.

It is difficult to imagine how these two candidates could share the stage for more than a few minutes without getting into a shouting match.

In short, there are a number of reasons why a Trump-Sanders debate is unlikely to happen. It is possible that the two candidates could agree to a debate for charity, but it is more likely that they will continue to attack each other from afar.

The policy would apply to any family that is caught crossing the border illegally, regardless of whether the child is a U.S. citizen. Children would be taken to shelters, while their parents would be detained in adult facilities. The administration has said that it will try to reunite the families as soon as possible, but it is unclear how long that will take.

The policy has been condemned by human rights groups, who say it is cruel and inhumane. They argue that it will traumatize children and make it difficult for families to be reunited. The policy has also been criticized by some legal experts, who say it may violate the Flores Agreement, a 1997 court settlement that sets standards for the treatment of immigrant children in U.S. custody.

The administration has defended the policy, saying that it is necessary to enforce the law and protect children. They argue that the policy is similar to policies that have been used in the past, and that it is not intended to be cruel.

It is unclear whether the administration will implement the policy. The policy is still being considered, and it is possible that it could be changed or abandoned. However, the fact that the administration is even considering such a policy has sparked a major debate about immigration policy in the United States.

The announcement came at the 23rd Conference of the Parties in Bonn, Germany, the world's biggest climate conference. The non-binding Paris accord, through which signatories pledge to reduce emissions of planet-warming gases over the coming decades, was brokered in 2015, when the annual conference was held in the French capital. The deal was considered historic because it was the first climate agreement to include the U.S. -- the world's biggest historic emitter, with by far the largest per-capita carbon footprint -- and China, which currently produces the most carbon pollution on a national level. The U.S. took a lead role in shaping the deal. Only war-torn Syria and Nicaragua, which protested the agreement's failure to impose strict demands on major polluters, refused to sign. But President Donald Trump, who rejects scientists' warnings about climate change, announced plans to withdraw from the pact in June, insisting developing nations received more benefits and the U.S. got none. In his announcement -- which, under the terms of the deal, fully can't go into effect until November 2020 -- Trump seemed to conflate the accord with a trade deal, demonstrating what was widely described as a poor understanding of how the Paris agreement actually works. In 2017, Syria, the United States, and Nicaragua were the three countries that had not ratified the Paris Agreement. However, in 2018, Syria joined the agreement, leaving the US as the only country not to have ratified it. The US withdrawal from the agreement has been met with widespread criticism, both domestically and internationally. Many have argued that the US is setting a bad example for other countries and that withdrawing from the agreement will make it more difficult to address climate change.

The Paris Agreement is a landmark international treaty on climate change. It was adopted by 196 parties at COP 21 in Paris on December 12, 2015, and entered into force on November 4, 2016. The agreement's central aim is to strengthen the global response to the threat of climate change by keeping a global temperature rise this century well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

The US is the world's second-largest emitter of greenhouse gases, after China. Its withdrawal from the Paris Agreement has been seen as a major setback for the global effort to combat climate change. The US has argued that the agreement is unfair to American businesses and that it will harm the US economy. However, many experts have disputed these claims. They argue that the US can actually benefit from the agreement by investing in clean energy and by creating new jobs in the clean energy sector.

The US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement has also had a negative impact on the global effort to mobilize private finance for climate change. Many investors have been reluctant to invest in projects in countries that are not party to the agreement. This is because they are concerned about the risk of these projects being stranded if the countries withdraw from the agreement or if the agreement is not implemented effectively.

The US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement has made it more difficult to address climate change. However, there is still hope that the agreement can be successful. The remaining parties to the agreement are committed to implementing the agreement and to achieving its goals. They are also working to address the challenges posed by the US withdrawal.

Right: Officials said Monday that the Obama administration-- in its waning hours-- defied Republican opposition and quietly released $221 million to the Palestinian Authority that GOP members of Congress had been blocking. A State Department official and several congressional aides told The Associated Press that the outgoing administration formally notified Congress it would spend the money Friday morning. The official said former Secretary of State John Kerry had informed some lawmakers of the move shortly before he left the State Department for the last time Thursday. The aides said written notification dated Jan. 20 was sent to Congress just hours before Donald Trump took the oath of office. In addition to the $221 million for the Palestinians, the Obama administration also told Congress on Friday it was going ahead with the release of another $6 million in foreign affairs spending, including $4 million for climate change programs and $1.25 million for U.N. organizations, the congressional aides said. response:
The US State Department admitted to deleting video from an archived press briefing which included statements it made about controversial American diplomatic talks with Iran. The deleted video was from a December 2013 press briefing, where then-spokeswoman Jen Psaki was asked about reported discrepancies in the start date of the Iran nuclear talks. Psaki had been asked about an earlier claim that no direct, secret talks were underway between the U.S. and Iran - when, in fact, they were. Psaki at the time seemed to admit the discrepancy, saying: 'There are times where diplomacy needs privacy in order to progress. This is a good example of that.'

However, Fox News later discovered the Psaki exchange was missing from the department's official website and its YouTube channel. Eight minutes from the briefing, including the comments on the Iran deal, were edited out and replaced with a white-flash effect. Officials initially suggested a 'glitch' occurred. But on Wednesday, current State Department spokesman Kirby said someone had censored the video intentionally. He said he couldn't find out who was responsible, but described such action as unacceptable. While saying there were 'no rules [or] regulations in place that prohibited' this at the time, Kirby said: 'Deliberately removing a portion of a public record is unacceptable and should not have happened.'

The deletion of the video has raised questions about transparency and accountability at the State Department. Some critics have suggested that the deletion was an attempt to cover up the Obama administration's role in the Iran nuclear talks. The State Department has denied that accusation, saying that the video was deleted because it was 'inadvertently' included in a batch of videos that were being deleted for technical reasons.

The deletion of the video is just the latest in a series of controversies involving the State Department's handling of public records. In recent years, the department has been criticized for its handling of email records, travel records, and other documents. The deletion of the video is likely to add to the perception that the State Department is not transparent and is not accountable to the public.

Left: WASHINGTON -- Former President Barack Obama said Tuesday that President Donald Trump's decision to dismantle the program protecting young undocumented immigrants was "contrary to our spirit, and to common sense." Trump announced Tuesday that he will end Obama's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA, in six months. Unless Congress steps in, ending the program could put nearly 800,000 undocumented young people at risk of deportation and unable to work legally when their two-year permits expire. Obama said it was a "political decision, and a moral question" -- and one of basic decency. "To target these young people is wrong -- because they have done nothing wrong," he said in a statement. "It is self-defeating -- because they want to start new businesses, staff our labs, serve in our military, and otherwise contribute to the country we love. And it is cruel. This is about whether we are a people who kick hopeful young strivers out of America, or whether we treat them the way we'd want our own kids to be treated. It's about who we are as a people -- and who we want to be." Obama started the program in 2012 and urged undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to come forward to the government, pay a fee and undergo a background check before receiving a two-year work permit and reprieve from deportation. He did so after legislative efforts to help Dreamers -- which are being revived now because of Trump's decisions -- failed multiple times, as he noted

"There's an energy revolution that's going to happen in this country," he said. The president also signed three other orders related to pipeline construction, including one expediting the environmental permitting process for infrastructure projects and one directing the Commerce Department to maximize the use of U.S. steel. The president was summoning top senators to the White House later Tuesday

These pipelines have been controversial since they were first proposed, and the Obama administration had blocked their construction. Trump's decision to approve them is a major victory for the oil industry and for his supporters in the business community.

The Keystone XL pipeline would carry oil from Canada's tar sands to refineries in the United States. The Dakota Access pipeline would carry oil from the Bakken oil fields in North Dakota to refineries in Illinois. Both pipelines have been opposed by environmental groups, who argue that they will contribute to climate change and damage the environment.

Trump's decision to approve the pipelines is likely to face legal challenges. Environmental groups have already vowed to sue to block the construction of the pipelines. It is also possible that Congress could pass legislation to block the pipelines. However, it is unlikely that Trump will be able to be stopped from building the pipelines.

Attorney General Jeff Sessions is scheduled to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday, June 7, 2017. Sessions is expected to answer questions about his role in the firing of FBI Director James Comey, as well as his contacts with Russian officials during the 2016 presidential campaign.

Sessions recused himself from the Justice Department's Russia investigation in March 2017, after acknowledging that he had met with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak twice during the campaign. However, he has continued to be involved in the investigation in some ways, including by meeting with President Donald Trump on multiple occasions to discuss the matter.

Comey's testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee last week raised new questions about Sessions' involvement in the Russia investigation. Comey testified that he felt pressured by Sessions to drop an investigation into former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn. Comey also said that Sessions had told him that he had "no earthly idea" why Trump had fired him.

Sessions is likely to face tough questions from Democrats on the Senate Intelligence Committee about his role in the Russia investigation. Democrats are expected to ask him about his contacts with Russian officials, his recusal from the investigation, and his meetings with Trump.

Republicans are likely to defend Sessions and try to portray him as a victim of a partisan witch hunt. They are also likely to ask Sessions about the FBI's handling of the Clinton email investigation.

Sessions' testimony is likely to be a major event in the ongoing Russia investigation. It will be the first time that Sessions has publicly answered questions about the matter, and it could provide new insights into his involvement.

Travelers are hurrying to their trains, tourists are gawking at the Harry Potter Platform 9 and 3/4, and there are virtually no security checks or extra police in sight. It's as if Saturday night's terrorist attack -- where three attackers armed with a rental van and knives killed at least seven and wounded 48 less than three miles away -- didn't happen. But while life in London might seem normal to most residents of the city, things very much are not. In a prepared speech on Sunday morning, UK Prime Minister Theresa May confirmed that the still-unnamed attackers at London Bridge and Borough Market were Islamist extremists. She also confirmed that the attackers had no known links with the attackers in two other recent UK terrorist attacks -- a van ramming pedestrians on Westminster Bridge in March and a suicide bombing at an Ariana Grande concert in May. "In terms of their planning and execution, the recent attacks are not connected," she said. "But we believe we are experiencing a new trend in the threat we face, as terrorism breeds terrorism, and perpetrators are inspired to attack not only on the basis of carefully-constructed plots after years of planning and training -- and not even as lone attackers radicalized online -- but by copying one another and often using the crudest of means of attack." Preventing this kind of attack is quite difficult. It's hard

May said the recent attacks, while "not connected by common networks," were connected by the thread of extremist Islamic ideology which "claims our Western values of freedom, democracy and human rights are incompatible with the religion of Islam." The first change, she said, was realizing that the solution is not a permanent counter-terrorism effort, but defeating the ideology itself through making people understand that "pluralistic British values" are "superior to anything offered" by an extremist ideology. response:
Theresa May's speech following the London Bridge attack was a call to action for the international community to work together to combat terrorism. She outlined four key areas where she believes change is needed:

1. **Defeating the ideology of extremism.** May said that the solution to terrorism is not simply to increase security measures, but to defeat the ideology of extremism itself. She called for a more proactive approach to countering extremist propaganda and ideology, and for working to build a more tolerant and inclusive society.
2. **Tackling the root causes of extremism.** May acknowledged that there are a number of factors that can contribute to radicalization, including poverty, inequality, and lack of opportunity. She called for a more comprehensive approach to addressing these issues, including investing in education and social programs.
3. **Strengthening international cooperation.** May said that the international community must work together to share intelligence, coordinate law enforcement efforts, and prevent the flow of funding to terrorist groups. She also called for greater cooperation on border security and travel restrictions.
4. **Protecting our values.** May said that the UK must stand up for its values of freedom, democracy, and human rights, even in the face of terrorism. She called on the British people to remain united and resilient in the face of these challenges.

May's speech was well-received by many, who praised her for her clear and concise message. However, some critics have pointed out that her proposals are unlikely to be easy to implement, and that they may not be enough to prevent future terrorist attacks. Nevertheless, May's speech is an important step in the fight against terrorism, and it is clear that the international community must do more to work together to address this global threat.

In addition to May's four key areas, there are a number of other things that can be done to combat terrorism. These include:

* **Investing in education and social programs.** As May noted, poverty, inequality, and lack of opportunity can all contribute to radicalization. By investing in education and social programs, we can help to create a more just and inclusive society, which will make it less likely that people will turn to violence.
* **Promoting tolerance and understanding.** One of the most effective ways to combat extremism is to promote tolerance and understanding between different groups of people. This can be done through education, media campaigns, and community outreach programs.
* **Tackling online radicalization.** The internet has become a major platform for extremist groups to spread their message. We need to work to counter this propaganda and to prevent young people from being radicalized online.
* **Strengthening border security.** We need to do more to prevent terrorists from entering our countries. This includes improving intelligence sharing, strengthening border controls, and cracking down on human smuggling.
* **Enhancing cooperation with other countries.** Terrorism is a global problem, and it can only be solved through international cooperation. We need to work with other countries to share intelligence, coordinate law enforcement efforts, and prevent the flow of funding to terrorist groups.

Tackling terrorism is a complex and difficult challenge, but it is one that we must face. By taking the steps outlined above, we can make our world a safer place.

Left: A single student's case has turned into a massive legal decision for all transgender Americans. On Tuesday, the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the Kenosha Unified School District in Wisconsin violated the rights of a trans student, Ash Whitaker, when it refused to let him use the boys' bathroom. According to the court, Whitaker is likely to win upon a full review of the case (instead of the current review of a lower court's preliminary injunction) on his claim that the school's actions violated Title IX, a federal law that prohibits discrimination in schools based on sex, and the Equal Protections Clause of the 14th Amendment. So it upheld a lower court's injunction forcing the school to let Whitaker use the bathroom that aligns with his gender identity. In the decision, a three-judge panel from the Seventh Circuit Court concluded that the school district "has failed to provide any evidence of how the preliminary injunction will harm it, or any of its students or parents" -- a rebuke of the prevalent myth that letting trans people use the bathroom for their gender identity will hurt others. The ruling has big implications: If existing federal law and the 14th Amendment shield trans people from discrimination, then it's not just Whitaker's rights that are protected here, but all trans students'. And if bans against sex discrimination in particular apply to trans people, then it's not just students' rights that are protected, but all trans people who face discrimination in other settings where sex discrimination is banned
Right: The federal constitution requires that school officials submit to the demands of a teenage girl who wants to change her sex to become a boy, says a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The judges say that Kenosha Unified School District violated federal law and the Constitution because the teenager's "gender identity" as a "transgender boy" is more important than the popular laws, civic customs and scientific consensus which recognize that girls and boys, men and women, are biologically and socially different even as they are also complementary and legally equal. The court's ruling in Whitaker v. Kenosha likely will be sent to the U.S. Supreme Court, which will likely decide in 2018 whether the new idea of "gender identity" will replace society's distinctions between girls and boys, and between men and women. response:
The United States successfully intercepted an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) during a test on Tuesday, the Missile Defense Agency (MDA) said.

The test occurred at the Ronald Reagan Ballistic Missile Defense Test Site on Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands. The MDA said the ground-based interceptor (GBI) launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California successfully collided with a target missile that was launched from the same site.

"The intercept of a complex, threat-representative ICBM target is an incredible accomplishment for the GMD system and a critical milestone for this program," said MDA Director Vice Adm. Jim Syring. "This system is vitally important to the defense of our homeland, and this test demonstrates that we have a capable, credible deterrent against a very real threat."

The test was the first time the MDA had successfully intercepted an ICBM target since 2013. It comes at a time of heightened tensions between the United States and North Korea, which has been testing ballistic missiles at an unprecedented rate in recent months.

The MDA said the test was "not a response to any specific threat" but was part of its ongoing efforts to "ensure the readiness of the GMD system."

The GMD system is designed to defend the United States against a limited number of ICBMs launched from North Korea or another country. The system consists of four interceptors at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California and four interceptors at Fort Greely in Alaska.

The interceptors are designed to destroy incoming ICBMs by colliding with them in mid-air. The MDA said the interceptors are equipped with "hit-to-kill" technology, which means they do not carry explosives. Instead, they destroy the incoming missile by colliding with it at high speeds.

The MDA said the test was "a significant achievement" for the GMD system. "This test demonstrates that we have a capable, credible deterrent against a very real threat," Syring said.

Left: ANNVILLE, Pa. -- Allison Jaslow heard it more than once as the long holiday weekend approached -- a cheerful "Happy Memorial Day!" from oblivious well-wishers. The former Army captain and Iraq War veteran had a ready reply, telling them, matter-of-factly, that she considered it a work weekend. Jaslow will be at Arlington National Cemetery on Monday to take part in the annual wreath-laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. She'll then visit Section 60, the final resting place of many service members who died in Iraq and Afghanistan. "You can see it in people's faces that they're a little horrified that they forget this is what the day's about," said Jaslow, 34, who wears a bracelet bearing the name of a fallen comrade. "Culturally, we've kind of lost sight of what the day's supposed to mean." While millions of Americans celebrate the long Memorial Day weekend as the unofficial start of summer -- think beaches and backyard barbecues, mattress sales and sporting events -- some veterans and loved ones of fallen military members wish the holiday that honors more than 1 million people who died serving their country would command more respect. Or at least awareness. "It's a fun holiday for people: 'Let's party.' It's an extra day off from work," said Carol Resh, 61, whose son, Army Capt. Mark Resh, was killed in Iraq a decade ago. Right: For many Americans, Memorial Day is nothing more than a cookout. But it began as a way to honor those who died in the Civil War, and heal a broken country. For many Americans, Memorial Day has become a nonchalant occasion to take Monday off work and gather with family and friends at a park or a backyard cookout. There's nothing wrong with that as far as it goes, but it's not what Memorial Day is really about. Memorial Day is of course about honoring our war dead. It was first instituted in the immediate aftermath of the Civil War, when there were countless war dead to honor, Union and Confederate. Back then it was called Decoration Day, as the point was to decorate the graves of the fallen with flowers. There's a lot we can learn today from understanding those early Memorial Days. After four years of a war that took the lives of some 620,000 Americans, Memorial Day was about remembering and honoring all who gave their lives, regardless of which uniform they wore. Recall that this was a time, much like our own, of deep divisions and rancor in America. Yet Americans then were able to honor the fallen of both sides, recognizing that each died valiantly fighting for a cause in which they believed. Today, it has become fashionable to remember Confederate soldiers and officers as nothing more than racist traitors--defenders of slavery whose memories should invite scorn and whose images should be stricken from public life. Trump arrived at the Vatican in a small elevator, and after a long ceremonial walk past frescoed corridors, shook the pope's hand at the entrance to the private study, which the frugal pope uses only for official occasions. On Friday, Congress approved a one-week spending measure that averted a shutdown on Saturday. In recent days, the spending talks on Capitol Hill had seemed unlikely to result in the kind of impasse that could lead to a shutdown, the last of which occurred in 2013. Some key obstacles, including the border wall and a standoff over subsidy payments to insurers under the Affordable Care Act, seemed to fall away as congressional negotiators worked on a deal. The White House said last week that it would continue to make the payments, and that message reassured Democrats who wanted to ensure that the payments, which go to insurers to lower deductibles and other out-of-pocket costs for low-income consumers, would not be cut off. Lawmakers were able to reach a resolution in the spending package on another potential sticking point, the fate of retired coal miners who faced losing their health coverage, an issue that brought lawmakers close to a government shutdown in December. response:
Republican and Democratic lawmakers forged a $1.07 trillion spending package that would fund the government through the end of September, but does not include some of President Trump's cornerstone promises including funding for a border wall or funding cuts to sanctuary cities.

The proposed legislation has no funding for Trump's oft-promised wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, but does set aside $1.5 billion for border security measures such as additional detention beds. It does give Trump a $12.5 billion down payment on his request to strengthen the military, a figure which could rise to $15 billion should Trump present Congress with a plan for fighting the Islamic State terror group. The proposed $15 billion amounts to half of Trump's original $30 billion request.

Trump said at nearly every campaign stop last year that Mexico would pay for the proposed 2,000-mile border wall, a claim Mexican leaders have broadly rejected. The White House sought nearly $1.4 billion in taxpayer dollars for the wall and related costs in the spending bill, but Trump later relented and said the issue could wait until September.

With language about the border wall omitted, Democratic leaders praised the effort.

'The bill ensures taxpayer dollars aren't used to fund an ineffective border wall, excludes poison pill riders, and increases investments in programs that the middle class relies on, like medical research, education and infrastructure,' Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., said in a statement

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., echoed Schumer's praise, saying in a separate statement 'the omnibus does not fund President Trump's reckless border wall, and instead provides critical investments in our communities.'

The bill also includes a number of other provisions, including funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program, which provides health insurance to millions of low-income children, and a measure to prevent a government shutdown on March 15.

The spending package is expected to pass both chambers of Congress with bipartisan support.

On April 15, 2017, a group of people called Tax March organized a march in Washington, D.C., and in other cities across the country to demand that President Trump release his tax returns. The march was the culmination of months of pressure from activists and journalists who have been trying to get Trump to release his tax returns since he announced his candidacy for president in June 2015. Trump is the first major party presidential nominee in decades to refuse to release his tax returns.

There are a number of reasons why people want to see Trump's tax returns. First, it is customary for presidential candidates to release their tax returns so that voters can see how they have made their money and whether they have any conflicts of interest. Second, Trump has made a number of claims about his wealth and his business dealings that have not been independently verified. Releasing his tax returns would provide evidence to support or refute these claims. Third, Trump has been accused of tax evasion and other financial crimes. Releasing his tax returns would allow investigators to examine these allegations.

Trump has refused to release his tax returns for a number of reasons. He has said that he is under audit by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and that releasing his returns would jeopardize the audit. However, there is no legal precedent for this claim. The IRS has said that it would not interfere with an audit if Trump were to release his tax returns.

Trump has also said that he does not want to release his tax returns because they are "very complex" and that people would not understand them. However, this claim is also not credible. Trump's tax returns would be subject to the same Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests as any other government document. If Trump were to release his tax returns, the public would be able to review them and make their own judgments about his finances.

The Tax March was a successful event in that it drew a large crowd and generated a lot of media attention. However, it is unclear whether it will succeed in getting Trump to release his tax returns. Trump has so far shown no willingness to comply with the public's demand for transparency.

response:
The GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast (MOAB), also known as the Mother of All Bombs, is a large-yield conventional bomb developed by the United States Air Force. It is the largest non-nuclear bomb ever used in combat by the U.S. military. The MOAB weighs 21,600 pounds (9,800 kg) and has a blast yield of 11 tons of TNT. It is a free-fall bomb that is parachuted to its target. The MOAB was first tested in March 2003 and was deployed to Afghanistan in May 2003. It was used for the first time in combat on April 13, 2017, against an ISIS tunnel complex in Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan.

The MOAB is a powerful weapon, but it is not a nuclear weapon. The blast yield of the MOAB is equivalent to 11 tons of TNT, while the blast yield of the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima was equivalent to 15 kilotons of TNT. The MOAB is also not as destructive as a nuclear weapon. The nuclear bomb dropped on Hiroshima destroyed an entire city, while the MOAB destroyed a much smaller area.

The MOAB was used in Afghanistan because it was the right weapon for the right target. The ISIS tunnel complex was heavily fortified and difficult to access. The MOAB was able to destroy the complex and eliminate the ISIS fighters who were inside.

The use of the MOAB in Afghanistan was controversial. Some people argued that it was a sign of escalation in the war, while others argued that it was a necessary tool to defeat ISIS. The use of the MOAB is likely to continue to be debated in the years to come.

The United States and its allies are facing a difficult dilemma in Syria. On the one hand, they want to see an end to the civil war and the suffering of the Syrian people. On the other hand, they do not want to see the Assad regime overthrown, as that could lead to chaos and instability in the region.

The U.S. has been trying to negotiate a political solution to the Syrian conflict, but so far these efforts have failed. The Assad regime has shown no willingness to negotiate with the opposition, and the various rebel groups have been unable to agree on a common platform.

In the absence of a political solution, the U.S. and its allies have been forced to resort to military action. The airstrikes on a Syrian air base last week were a response to the use of chemical weapons by the Assad regime. The U.S. hopes that these airstrikes will deter the Assad regime from using chemical weapons again, and that they will also pressure Russia to pressure the Assad regime to negotiate a political solution.

However, it is not clear whether the airstrikes will achieve these goals. The Assad regime has shown a disregard for human life, and it is not clear that they will be deterred by the use of military force. Russia is also unlikely to pressure the Assad regime to negotiate a political solution, as they are a close ally of the Assad regime.

The U.S. and its allies are therefore facing a difficult choice. They can either continue to use military force in an attempt to pressure the Assad regime, or they can try to negotiate a political solution. It is not clear which option is more likely to succeed, and the U.S. and its allies are likely to continue to face a difficult dilemma in Syria for some time to come.

On April 9, 2017, two suicide bombings took place in the Egyptian cities of Tanta and Alexandria. The attacks targeted Coptic Christian churches and killed at least 44 people and injured more than 100 others. The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) claimed responsibility for the attacks.

The first bombing took place at St. George Church in Tanta, a city in the Nile Delta. The second bombing took place at St. Mark's Cathedral in Alexandria, the seat of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria.

Both attacks were carried out by suicide bombers who detonated explosives as they entered the churches. The attacks came during Palm Sunday services, a major holiday for Christians.

The attacks were the deadliest against Christians in Egypt in recent years. They have raised concerns about the security of Christians in Egypt, where they make up about 10% of the population.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi condemned the attacks and vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice. He declared a three-month state of emergency and ordered the deployment of troops to protect churches across the country.

The United States, the European Union, and other countries condemned the attacks and offered their condolences to the victims. They also called on Egypt to take all necessary measures to protect its citizens and to bring the perpetrators to justice.

The attacks are a reminder of the ongoing threat posed by ISIS and other extremist groups. They also highlight the challenges facing Christians in Egypt, who have been targeted by violence for many years.

Right: WASHINGTON - President Trump ordered a cruise missile strike against a Syrian regime military airbase, in response to a chemical weapons attack carried out by the regime earlier this week. At 8:40 p.m. EDT, the U.S. launched 59 Tomahawk land attack missiles at the Shayrat Airfield located in the Homs Governorate in Western Syria, according to Pentagon officials. The strike lasted minutes. "This was in response to the Syrian chemical weapons attack April 4th in Khan Sheikhoun... That attack killed and injured hundreds of innocent Syrian people, including women and children," said Pentagon spokesman Navy Capt. Jeff Davis. "The strikes were intended to deter the regime from using chemical weapons again," he said. The missiles were launched from U.S. destroyers USS Porter and Ross, which were in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea at the time, he said. The missiles hit aircraft, hardened aircraft shelters, petroleum and logistical storage areas, ammunition supply bunkers, air defense systems and radars, he said. Davis said the U.S. military took care to avoid any human casualties. It notified Russia - and "many countries" - of the planned strikes ahead of time. There were Russian troops at the airbase, although it' is not clear if they were still there during the strikes. Davis said the U.S. struck an area where Russian and Syrian troops were not located. "In this case in particular, every precaution was taken to execute these strikes with minimal risk to personnel at the airfield," Davis said. The strike was aimed at deterring another chemical weapons attack by the regime.

YAZAN AL-SAADI: Well, my first response is that WASHINGTON - President Trump ordered a cruise missile strike against a Syrian regime military airbase, in response to a chemical weapons attack carried out by the regime earlier this week. At 8:40 p.m. EDT, the U.S. launched 59 Tomahawk land attack missiles at the Shayrat Airfield located in the Homs Governorate in Western Syria, according to Pentagon officials. The strike lasted minutes. 'This was in response to the Syrian chemical weapons attack April 4th in Khan Sheikhoun... That attack killed and injured hundreds of innocent Syrian people, including women and children,' said Pentagon spokesman Navy Capt. Jeff Davis. 'The strikes were intended to deter the regime from using chemical weapons again,' he said. The missiles were launched from U.S. destroyers USS Porter and Ross, which were in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea at the time, he said. The missiles hit aircraft, hardened aircraft shelters, petroleum and logistical storage areas, ammunition supply bunkers, air defense systems and radars, he said. Davis said the U.S. military took care to avoid any human casualties. It notified Russia - and 'many countries' - of the planned strikes ahead of time. There were Russian troops at the airbase, although it' is not clear if they were still there during the strikes. Davis said the U.S. struck an area where Russian and Syrian troops were not located. 'In this case in particular, every precaution was taken to execute these strikes with minimal risk to personnel at the airfield,' Davis said. The strike was aimed at deterring another chemical weapons attack by the regime.
response:
The U.S. military launched a cruise missile strike against a Syrian regime military airbase on April 7, 2017, in response to a chemical weapons attack carried out by the regime earlier that week. The strike was aimed at deterring another chemical weapons attack by the regime.

The strike was condemned by Russia and Iran, who are allies of the Syrian regime. Russia said the strike was a "violation of international law" and that it would "undermine the process of political settlement in Syria." Iran said the strike was "a dangerous escalation of tensions" and that it would "not help to resolve the crisis in Syria."

The strike was welcomed by the Syrian opposition and its allies. The Syrian National Coalition, the main Syrian opposition group, said the strike was "a necessary step" to deter the Syrian regime from using chemical weapons again. The United States and its allies have repeatedly warned the Syrian regime not to use chemical weapons, but the regime has ignored these warnings.

The use of chemical weapons in Syria is a violation of international law. The Chemical Weapons Convention, which Syria is a party to, prohibits the use, development, production, stockpiling, and transfer of chemical weapons. The Syrian regime has used chemical weapons on multiple occasions during the Syrian civil war.

The U.S. military strike on the Shayrat Airbase was the first time the U.S. has used military force in Syria since the start of the Syrian civil war in 2011. The strike was a limited strike, and it is not clear whether it will deter the Syrian regime from using chemical weapons again. The U.S. and its allies will need to continue to pressure the Syrian regime to comply with international law and to stop using chemical weapons.

Left: "It is depressing; I'm very depressed," Republican Sen. John McCain said this week. "We're going down the wrong path here," Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin said. They were both talking about the same thing: the GOP's potential use of the so-called "nuclear option" to confirm Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court. Senate Republicans will move to a vote Thursday on Gorsuch's nomination. Senate Democrats are expected to filibuster to block that vote. And in response, the Republicans will likely change the rules of the Senate to eliminate the filibuster for Supreme Court nominations, so all Gorsuch needs is a simple majority of votes to be confirmed. Senators from both parties are unhappy with this unusual rule change, but it's almost certainly going to happen anyway. I wanted to know if Republicans' use of the nuclear option represents a high-water mark for partisanship in American history. I also wanted to know what it would mean for the minority party in the Senate moving forward, why the nomination process has become so contentious, and what, if anything, can be done about the partisan gridlock. So I reached out to Brian Balogh, co-host of the BackStory With the American History Guys podcast and a professor of history at the University of Virginia. Balogh's research focuses on the evolution of American political parties and movements. I also reached out to Sarah Binder, a professor of political science at George Washington University. Binder is the author of Stalemate: Causes and Consequences of Legislative Gridlock, which examines 50 years of legislative history
Right: UPDATE - Harry Reid's legacy is thus cemented. Democrats' unprecedented filibuster of Judge Neil Gorsuch has been broken under the nuclear option they pioneered in 2013. Every single Republican voted to invoke the Reid Rule, including some who had expressed a strong hesitancy to do so; that's how indefensible Democrats' conduct has been. The Senate will now reach cloture on the nomination with 51 votes, setting up a final confirmation tomorrow. It's over. This is the first partisan filibuster of a SCOTUS nominee in American history. The only previous High Court filibuster was a nearly evenly bipartisan act against a sitting justice embroiled in an ethical controversy in 1968; its target later resigned. This is an entirely partisan tantrum, advanced after multiple attempts to discredit Judge Gorsuch fell humiliatingly flat. Senate Democrats do not have one single good argument against Gorsuch, nor do they have one single principled rationalization of a filibuster. And yet... And there it is: 41 Democrat votes have been cast in favor of this unprecedented SCOTUS filibuster. The Reid Rule 'nuclear' option

The use of the nuclear option by Republicans to confirm Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court represents a high-water mark for partisanship in American history. It is a sign of the deep divisions that exist in the country and the willingness of both parties to use extreme measures to achieve their goals.

The nuclear option is a term used to describe the process of changing the rules of the Senate in order to reduce the number of votes required to end a filibuster. In the past, a filibuster required 60 votes to end, which meant that the minority party could block a nomination or legislation even if the majority party had a majority of seats in the Senate. However, in 2013, then-Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) invoked the nuclear option to reduce the number of votes required to end a filibuster for lower court nominations from 60 to 51. This change was made in response to Republican obstruction of President Barack Obama's judicial nominees.

The use of the nuclear option by Republicans to confirm Gorsuch is a direct response to Reid's decision in 2013. Republicans argue that they are simply following the precedent set by Democrats. However, Democrats argue that the nuclear option is a dangerous precedent that will further erode the Senate's ability to function as a deliberative body.

The use of the nuclear option by Republicans to confirm Gorsuch is likely to have a significant impact on the future of the Supreme Court. It will make it much easier for future presidents to appoint justices who share their views, regardless of the views of the minority party. This could lead to a more ideologically divided Court, which would make it more difficult for the Court to reach consensus on important issues.

The use of the nuclear option is also likely to have a negative impact on the Senate as a whole. It will make it more difficult for the Senate to pass legislation, as the minority party will be able to block any bill that does not have the support of 60 senators. This could lead to a more gridlocked government, which would make it more difficult to address the country's problems.

The use of the nuclear option by Republicans to confirm Gorsuch is a major step towards a more partisan and dysfunctional government. It is a sign that both parties are willing to use extreme measures to achieve their goals, even if it means damaging the institutions of government.

Left: Russia St Petersburg metro explosion leaves 11 dead and dozens wounded Vladimir Putin holds meeting with security chiefs following blast on train between Sennaya Ploshchad and Tekhnologicheskii Institut metro stations Deadly explosion on St Petersburg metro train The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, held a meeting with security chiefs late on Monday night as security officials investigated a bomb blast on a St Petersburg metro train that killed 11 people and wounded dozens more. A second explosive device was left at a different metro station but did not detonate. Police initially said the device had been left on the train by the attacker, and that a search was under way for two people suspected of organising and carrying out the attack. Later, however, the Interfax news agency claimed the blast had in fact been caused by a suicide bomber, citing a law enforcement source, but there was no immediate confirmation of this. The explosion occurred at around 2.30pm local time on Monday, after the train had left Sennaya Ploshchad station in the centre of St Petersburg. The driver made the decision to continue to the next station, Tekhnologicheskii Institut, in order to make evacuation easier. Those on the train spoke of a blast that was mainly felt in the carriage where it occurred, three from the front of the train. "I don't think it was that loud, but then I was wearing headphones," said Andrei Shurshev, who was in the next carriage along. He told the Russian news site Meduza that after the blast there were some sparks and dust in his carriage, and a smell of smoke. "We went to the end of the carriage and got out at the station. In the next carriage there were no lights, and a lot of smoke.
Right: 14 are believed to have been killed and over 30 wounded after an explosion on the Saint Petersburg metro on Monday afternoon. Read the original story below. Russia's international news agency RIA Novosti reports the Russian President Vladimir Putin has been alerted to the explosion, which the agency calls an "attack". It is possible there have been up to ten fatalities and dozens of injured, according to the agency. According to reports in Russian-language media several casualties have been reported at the Institute of Technology station, and Sennaya Square station of the Saint Petersburg metro. Security services and medical first responders are on the scene. All central Saint Petersburg metro stations have been closed, and security provision has been stepped up in other Russian cities including the capital, Moscow. Vladimir Putin has expressed condolences and said the state security services were looking into "all positive motives", including terror motives. Several users of social media have shared images and videos that purport to come from the scene. One shared to YouTube shows a smoke-filled concourse between platforms. Other pictures shared through Twitter apparently show a wrecked train carriage and victims of the blast laid out on the platforms, with what appears to be blood smeared on the white marble columns that support the station's roof. This story is developing

response:
A bomb blast on a metro train in St Petersburg, Russia, on Monday killed at least 11 people and injured dozens more. The explosion occurred at around 2.30pm local time, as the train was travelling between Sennaya Ploshchad and Tekhnologicheskii Institut stations. The cause of the blast is still under investigation, but it is believed to have been caused by a suicide bomber.

The blast caused extensive damage to the train and the station, and witnesses described seeing bodies and debris strewn across the platform. The injured were taken to hospital, where many are said to be in critical condition.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has condemned the attack, which he described as a "terrorist act". He has ordered security forces to step up their efforts to combat terrorism, and has vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice.

The attack is the latest in a series of terrorist attacks in Russia in recent years. In 2017, a suicide bomber killed at least 16 people at a metro station in Moscow. And in 2018, a bomb attack on a concert hall in the city of Kerch killed at least 21 people.

The attacks have raised concerns about the threat of terrorism in Russia. The country has been battling an Islamist insurgency in the North Caucasus region for decades, and the attacks have shown that the threat of terrorism extends to major cities like Moscow and St Petersburg.

The Russian government has responded to the attacks by increasing security measures and cracking down on suspected terrorists. But the attacks have also led to a rise in anti-Muslim sentiment in Russia.

The attack on the St Petersburg metro is a reminder of the threat of terrorism in Russia. The government will need to do more to combat terrorism, and to address the underlying causes of the violence.

response:
House Bill 2 (HB2) was a law in North Carolina that was passed in March 2016. The law prohibited transgender people from using the bathroom that corresponds with their gender identity in government buildings and public schools. It also blocked local governments from passing their own anti-discrimination ordinances. HB2 was widely seen as discriminatory against transgender people, and it led to boycotts of North Carolina businesses and sporting events.

In March 2017, North Carolina Republican lawmakers and Democratic Gov. Roy Cooper agreed on a compromise to repeal HB2. The compromise law, called House Bill 142, repealed HB2 but also reinstated some of its provisions. For example, HB142 required transgender people to use the bathroom that corresponds with their sex assigned at birth in government buildings and public schools. It also prevented local governments from passing their own anti-discrimination ordinances for six months.

The compromise law was met with mixed reactions. Some people praised it for repealing HB2, while others criticized it for not going far enough to protect transgender people. The law was also challenged in court, and in August 2018, a federal judge struck down HB142.

The HB2 controversy was a major setback for LGBTQ rights in the United States. It showed that even in states with relatively progressive laws on the books, transgender people are still vulnerable to discrimination. The controversy also highlighted the need for federal legislation to protect LGBTQ people from discrimination.

There are a number of reasons why Democrats are calling for House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes to recuse himself from the Russia investigation.

First, Nunes has repeatedly shown that he is not impartial. He has made public statements that support the Trump administration's position on the investigation, and he has met with White House officials about the matter. This raises concerns that he is not able to conduct a fair and objective investigation.

Second, Nunes has access to sensitive intelligence information that he has not shared with other committee members. This gives him an unfair advantage, and it makes it difficult for Democrats to trust him to conduct a thorough investigation.

Finally, Nunes's recusal would help to restore public confidence in the investigation. The fact that he has met with White House officials and made public statements that support the Trump administration has raised questions about his impartiality. Recusing himself would allow the committee to continue its work without these concerns hanging over it.

Republicans have argued that Nunes is not required to recuse himself, and that he is the best person to lead the investigation. However, Democrats believe that his recusal is necessary to ensure the integrity of the investigation.

response:
Preet Bharara was fired on March 11, 2017, after refusing to resign from his position as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. Bharara had been appointed to the position by President Barack Obama in 2009, and he had been a vocal critic of President Donald Trump's administration.

The Department of Justice had asked all 46 of the nation's U.S. attorneys to resign on Friday, March 10, 2017. Bharara was one of the few U.S. attorneys who refused to resign, and he was fired by acting Deputy Attorney General Dana Boente on Saturday, March 11, 2017.

Bharara's firing was met with widespread criticism, with many people accusing President Trump of trying to interfere with the Justice Department. Bharara himself said that he was fired because he was "doing my job."

In a statement released after his firing, Bharara said:

"I did not resign. Moments ago I was fired. Being the US Attorney in SDNY will forever be the greatest honor of my professional life. Thank you to the incredible men and women of the Office for your sacrifice and service. I wish them all the best as they continue their outstanding work."

Bharara's firing is a major development in the ongoing battle between President Trump and the Justice Department. It remains to be seen how Bharara's firing will impact the ongoing investigations into President Trump's campaign and administration.

Left: Earlier today, the Bureau of Labor Statistics released payroll data that showed the U.S. added 235,000 jobs in February. Naturally, Donald Trump commemorated the event on his favorite social- media platform, retweeting the Drudge Report headline "GREAT AGAIN: +235,000," while his chief of staff, Reince Priebus,tweeted ".@POTUS Trump delivers in first #JobsReport. 235,000 new jobs and unemployment rate down to 4.7%. Great news for American workers!" What Team Trump didn't mention, though, was that in February 2016, the U.S. added 237,000 jobs and in February 2015, it added 238,000, accomplishments for which Trump was loathe to give Barack Obama credit. Doing so would throw a wrench in Team Trump's narrative, that under his predecessor, the country was a post-apocalyptic wasteland where the unemployment rate was 42 percent. Unfortunately, not everyone in the administration got the memo that presumably read "ANYTHING POSITIVE THAT HAPPENS MUST BE ATTRIBUTED TO TRUMP, NO EXCEPTIONS!" And that someone was National Economic Council director Gary Cohn. Per Business Insider: During an interview with CNBC, Cohn said the report was "right exactly where it needed to be," but he also said that Trump's team wasn't the reason for the beat. For one thing, Cohn said, the jobs that were promised by C.E.O.s who have met with Trump haven't been created yet. "Look, there's clearly a good February as part of the number. I'm not going to deny that," Cohn said. "But on the other hand, when you look at what we've been doing here at the White House and all of the C.E.O.s that we've brought in--whether it be Exxon or Sprint
Right: President Trump, who as a candidate often criticized the government's jobs' reports during the Obama administration as "phony," became a believer on Friday. The Labor Department, now part of the Trump administration, reported Friday that employers added 235,000 jobs in Mr. Trump's first full month in office, and the unemployment rate dropped slightly to 4.7 percent. A grinning White House press secretary Sean Spicer said he specifically asked the president Friday morning if he believed the new jobs report. "They may have been phony in the past, but it's very real now," Mr. Trump told his spokesman. After the New Hampshire Republican primary last year, Mr. Trump said, "Don't believe those phony numbers when you hear 4.9 and 5 percent unemployment. The number's probably 28, 29, as high as 35. In fact, I even heard recently 42 percent." Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez said the strong hiring numbers in February were due to the policies of the previous administration. "Thanks, Obama!" he said. Mr. Spicer said Mr. Trump's actions clearly are having an impact with employers. Asked at the daily press briefing whether Mr. Trump tweeted prematurely about the positive jobs report, Mr. Spicer retorted to a journalist, "Don't make me make the podium move." It was a reference to "Saturday Night Live," where Melissa McCarthy portrays Mr. Spicer in command of a mobile podium that he plows into the assembled reporters when annoyed. The accusation that Trump was wiretapped by Obama is a serious one, and it's important to understand the evidence behind it. Trump has made the accusation several times, but he has never provided any evidence to support it. In fact, the evidence that we do have suggests that Trump's claim is false.

First, it's important to understand how wiretapping works. The government can only wiretap someone if it has a warrant from a FISA court. A FISA warrant is a very high bar to clear, and it requires the government to show that there is probable cause to believe that the person being wiretapped is an agent of a foreign power.

In order to get a FISA warrant, the government must submit an application to the court. This application must include detailed information about the person being wiretapped, as well as the reasons why the government believes that person is an agent of a foreign power. The application must also be approved by a judge, who is supposed to independently review the evidence and make a decision based on the law.

So, what evidence does the government have to support Trump's claim that he was wiretapped? Well, the answer is: none. The government has never released any evidence to support Trump's claim, and there is no evidence that has been leaked to the press that supports it either.

In fact, the evidence that we do have suggests that Trump's claim is false. For example, we know that the FBI was investigating Trump's campaign for possible ties to Russia. However, we also know that the FBI did not have any evidence to support the claim that Trump was an agent of a foreign power. In fact, the FBI's investigation was based on the Steele dossier, which was a collection of unverified and largely discredited allegations.

So, what is the explanation for Trump's claim? Well, it's possible that he is simply lying. It's also possible that he is misremembering or misunderstanding something. Or, it's possible that he is being misled by someone who is trying to damage him.

Whatever the explanation, it's clear that Trump's claim that he was wiretapped by Obama is false. There is no evidence to support it, and the evidence that we do have suggests that it is false.
